message: With just hours until the 115th Congress begins, House Republicans are working to change the rules and gut the independent Office of Congressional Ethics. As the League of Women Voters of the U.S. says, this action gives "a green light to Congressional corruption."   If President-elect Donald Trump and Republicans are serious about "draining the swamp" and ending corruption, they should join me in strongly opposing this 11th hour abuse of power.

Moments ago, I was honored to take the oath of office to represent Minnesota's Fourth District in the United States House of Representatives for the 115th Congress. I am very grateful to the families of the Fourth District for giving me the opportunity to represent our shared values in the U.S. House of Representatives.  With Republicans controlling both the U.S. House and Senate and Donald Trump set to become President of the United States, our Minnesota values will be under serious threat in the 115th Congress. You can count on me to represent your voices by standing up and speaking out against policies that harm Minnesotans and our way of life.

ICYMI: I was honored to be sworn-in today to represent the families of Minnesota's Fourth District in the U.S. House of Representatives.   Sadly, the Trump-Republican agenda for the next two years would make it harder for us to build a stronger America where everyone has the opportunity to participate and succeed.  With our Minnesota values under threat in the 115th Congress, I intend to keeping standing up and speaking out for the constituents and families I represent. Learn more here → http://bit.ly/2iwqRod.

I joined House Democrats' meeting with President Obama today to thank him for his tireless leadership to build a stronger America where everyone has the opportunity to contribute and succeed.   We also talked about the success of the Affordable Care Act. This critical law has expanded access to health coverage and protected consumers, including stopping insurance companies from discriminating against people with pre-existing conditions. We must keep fighting to guarantee that all Minnesotans and Americans have access to quality, affordable health care.
I am very proud to be one of 65 House Democratic women in the 115th Congress. Together, we are fighting for our shared values and for all of America's women and working families!

House Republicans are now leading a reading of the United States Constitution on the House Floor, but actions speak louder than words.   House and Senate Republicans must join Democrats, enforce the Constitution's Emoluments Clause, and stop President-elect Donald Trump from profiting off the Presidency by taking money from foreign governments.

I spoke on the House Floor this afternoon about the Affordable Care Act and the tremendous positive impact it has had for working families.   For the sake of all Minnesotans and Americans who are no longer uninsured, who are protected from discriminated based on pre-existing conditions, and who now get free, high-quality preventive care, we must join together and save the Affordable Care Act.

We cannot go back to the days when being a woman was a pre-existing condition and coverage for essential women's health care was not covered by many insurance plans.   That's why I stood with Cecile Richards, Planned Parenthood, House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, and House Democrats today saying: #ProtectOurCare.

I am holding town hall meetings on Jan. 18 and Jan. 26 to discuss my work in Washington and to listen to your views on the issues that matter to you and your family.  I hope many of you will be able to attend one or both of these events and share your views with me directly. Full details here → http://mccollum.house.gov/jan2017-town-halls.

In December 2008, just before Barack Obama took office, our country — mired in the Great Recession— lost 524,000 jobs.  Thanks to President Obama's steady leadership and to the Democratic policies we enacted, our country has added 15.8 million jobs since 2010 and is currently experiencing a record 75-month streak of job growth.   While we have more work to do to ensure that every American is able to share in the economic recovery, we cannot turn back now on the progress we have made.

Minnesota would lose more than 52,000 jobs in 2019 alone if the ACA is repealed, according to new research from The Commonwealth Fund and the Milken Institute School of Public Health — two nonpartisan, highly-respected research institutions.  For the sake of thousands of Minnesota workers, we must stand together and save the Affordable Care Act!

This morning, 140 airmen from the 934th Airlift Wing — the Global Vikings — of the United States Air Force Reserve began a four-month deployment to Southwest Asia, where they will fly C-130 Hercules cargo aircraft and both airdrop and airland cargo and people.  I know all Minnesotans join me in standing with these citizen Airmen and their families during this deployment.

Need help with a federal agency? My staff will be holding office hours in Stillwater TOMORROW from 9 to 11 a.m. to help answer your questions. If you can't make it, you can call my St. Paul office any time for help at  651-224-9191.

With evidence that President-elect Donald Trump and his immediate family members are already trying to use the prestige of the highest office in the land to make money, I am co-sponsoring the Presidential Conflicts of Interest Act to require all Presidents and Vice Presidents to disclose and divest all potential financial conflicts of interest.  The American people deserve an accountable and transparent White House, not an administration that is focused on private gain over public good.

National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day is an opportunity for us to thank, honor, and remember the service of law enforcement officers from the federal to the township level.   As we commemorate LEAD today, our hearts are heavy for the family and friends of the police officer killed in the line of duty in Orlando. Her death is another reminder of the sacrifices made by all those who serve and protect our communities.

It was a bittersweet farewell today to U.S. Department of the Interior Secretary Sally Jewell. I have been honored to collaborate with her to preserve our nation's natural and cultural treasures — including Minnesota's Boundary Waters. Her work has truly embodied the proverb: "We do not inherit the Earth from our ancestors, we borrow it from our children."   Secretary Jewell's leadership for our environment and for our Native American brothers and sisters, particularly Native youth, will be long remembered and sorely missed.

General John F. Kelly — President-elect Donald Trump’s nominee for Secretary of Homeland Security — has a distinguished record of serving our country, including as Commander of the United States Southern Command. However, the Department of Homeland Security has responsibility over several areas in which President-elect Trump has made particularly disturbing campaign promises.  I hope that the Senators considering the Kelly nomination will receive robust assurances that General Kelly will stand up to President-elect Trump and his advisers when necessary to protect the civil liberties of Americans and ensure that immigrants are treated with dignity and respect.

House Republicans will likely vote this week on a budget resolution that will help them repeal the Affordable Care Act.   Their budget plan would cause 20 MILLION Americans to lose their health coverage while still adding $9.5 TRILLION to our national debt.   I strongly oppose this cruel and fiscally irresponsible budget plan. We must join together and fight to save the ACA.

We cannot allow Donald Trump or his family to profit from the Presidency. Faced with tremendous and dangerous conflicts of interests, Trump today once again refused to disclose his holdings, divest his assets, or place them in a blind trust.  The Office of Government Ethics, the official federal ethics watchdog, has said Trump's plan to hand over his business to his sons is "wholly inadequate." I agree. The American people deserve an accountable, transparent government, not a President focused on his personal profit.

I just voted NO on H.R. 5, a Republican bill that guts the creation and implementation of federal rules that ensure food safety, protect consumers, guarantee financial stability, and keep our nation's air and water clean.   Instead of passing yet another giveaway to corporate special interests, House Republicans should be taking up legislation that helps working families in Minnesota and across America.

As we transition from President Obama's steady and effective leadership to the administration of President-elect Donald Trump, there are many important issues to discuss. I hope to hear from you directly about your priorities and concerns at my town hall meetings on Jan. 18 and 26.   Learn more → http://mccollum.house.gov/jan2017-town-halls.

Congratulations, Vice President Biden, on receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom! Thank you for your tireless advocacy for working families and for all Americans. We are a better country for your service.

House Republicans have just brought up a legislative vehicle that will allow them to repeal the Affordable Care Act in the coming months. Their budget resolution adds $9.5 TRILLION to our national debt while cutting more than 20 MILLION Americans off their health insurance.   The only winners from this fuzzy math? Insurance and drug companies who will once again be able to profit from controlling your health care. That is unacceptable and I will keep fighting to #ProtectOurCare.

I proudly stood up for the Affordable Care Act this afternoon and voted against the Trump-Republican budget resolution that would begin to repeal this life-saving law.   We should be working together to further reduce costs and improve the quality of care, not tearing away insurance from millions of Americans and putting drug and insurance companies back in control of our healthcare system. #ProtectOurCare

I will be holding town hall meetings on Jan. 18 and Jan. 26 to hear directly from you about your priorities and concerns as we transition to the Trump administration.  Learn more and join us → http://mccollum.house.gov/jan2017-town-halls.

President-elect Donald Trump and Congressional Republicans are working right now to repeal the Affordable Care Act. This life-saving law works for ALL Americans: it has expanded access to coverage, made insurance more affordable, and put an end to insurance company abuses like annual and lifetime limits on coverage and discrimination based on pre-existing conditions. Repealing this law would hand control of health care back to big insurance and drug companies and cause more than 20 million people to lose their insurance.  On today's National Day of Action to Save Health Care, I need your help: I am asking you to join me in fighting to keep Minnesota healthy, to help our seniors, to protect our families from losing insurance, and to maintain vital consumer protections that keep our communities strong.

The Affordable Care Act has provided health security and dramatically improved the lives of our families, friends, neighbors, and co-workers – of ALL Americans. While I support common sense changes to the ACA to further reduce costs while supporting better quality care, Republicans have refused to work with us to make the ACA work even better for the American people. Instead, they have turned this law into a political weapon and refused to come up with a replacement plan.  You can count on me to fight every Republican effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act and put at risk the health and financial well-being of millions of Americans.

President-elect Donald Trump's behavior and policy proposals before, during, and after the November 8 election is repugnant to the values on which the United States was built and that Minnesotans hold dear. In the coming months, I have faith in our Constitutional democracy and in the power of citizen action to stop Mr. Trump's dangerous agenda.  On Friday, I will join President Obama and Secretary Clinton for the inauguration of our 45th President, a ritual that is a hallmark of our democratic government. I will also be present so Mr. Trump fully understands that, from the halls of Congress to the streets of our communities, Americans are already working to stop him from further hurting our country.  That’s a fight I will join in person, alongside thousands of Minnesotans, at the Women’s March in St. Paul on Saturday.

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office just released its analysis of Republican plans to repeal the Affordable Care Act.   If House Republicans' proposal to repeal the ACA is passed, 32 million Americans will become uninsured and insurance premiums in the individual market will double. (You can read the full CBO report here: http://bit.ly/2jvh0zx.)  This outcome would be devastating to Minnesota families. You can count on me to keep fighting to save the Affordable Care Act and to protect our care.

It was good to meet today with the Ramsey County, Minnesota Board and discuss federal policy priorities that could impact Ramsey County and its residents.  In particular, we talked about how Republican plans to repeal the Affordable Care Act would be devastating to Minnesota families. We must save the ACA.
REMINDER: I'm holding a town hall meeting tonight from 6:30 to 7:30 p.m. at Highland Park Community Center. There is a lot to talk about and I look forward to hearing from you directly.

The core mission of the Department of the Interior is to protect public lands and endangered species, preserve our national and natural heritage, and uphold our obligations to Native Americans.   I am deeply concerned that President-elect Trump and Representative Ryan Zinke — Trump's nominee for Secretary of the Interior — plan to pursue policies sharply at odds with that core mission, particularly when it comes to the environment. If they do, you can count on me to fight them every step of the way.

I had a great meeting today with Minnesota leaders in national service and volunteerism.  Special thanks to Amy Meuers of the National Youth Leadership Council for organizing the meeting. Minnesota is the nation’s leader in service and we must ensure strong federal support for the Corporation for National and Community Service. Count me in as a strong supporter!

Thank you to the standing room only crowd that joined me for my first 2017 town hall tonight! I appreciated the robust discussion of the issues that matter most to you.  With an overflow crowd, we had to turn some attendees away tonight and I apologize for the inconvenience. If you couldn't make it — or couldn't make it in the hall — tonight, I hope to see you on Thursday, Jan. 26 at 6:30 p.m. at Neighborhood House at the Wellstone Center for another town hall meeting. I'll also be announcing additional town halls soon.

President Donald Trump's inaugural address was a dark and frightening vision of an America divided at home and isolated in the world. Instead of appealing to the better angels of our nature, President Trump has decided to sow more division with warmed over campaign rhetoric.  I completely reject President Trump's disturbing vision for our country. We are already a great nation and we must protect our future from this President's dangerous policies. There will be no Presidential honeymoon this year: I am ready to stand up to Trump now.

I wore this pin at the inauguration of President Trump today as an act of silent protest to send a clear message: we will fight back against his dangerous agenda, beginning with protecting our care and saving the Affordable Care Act for the benefit of all Americans.

I'll join thousands of Minnesotans tomorrow for the Women's March Minnesota. We'll march for our rights, our safety, our health care, and the well-being of our communities. I hope to see you there! #WhyWeMarch
I'm honored to be with a huge crowd of thousands of Minnesota women and families for today's Women's March Minnesota!

Today was an amazing, inspiring day as I joined a crowd of 100,000 Minnesotans in the Women's March Minnesota.   For our daughters, our mothers, our sisters, and for ourselves, we must stand together because there are politicians in Washington and in St. Paul who want to take our rights away from us. We are in a fight, we will not back down, and we will not be stopped!

I spoke today at the Women's March Minnesota about how we fight back against President Donald Trump and Congressional Republicans' despicable agenda. Here's some of what I said:  "Women are marching and rallying today across the country to send a loud, clear message to President Trump and his right-wing Congress: Keep your hands off our bodies! Keep your hands off our healthcare! Keep your hands off Planned Parenthood! Keep your backwards agenda out of workplaces, out of our schools, and out of our communities.  To all my sisters – white and black; Christian, Muslim and Jewish; Native American, Latina, and Asian-American; gay and straight; mother, grandmother and granddaughter; whomever we are, we must stand together, we must stay organized together, we must fight for all of our rights together, and we must never quit."  Read my full remarks → http://bit.ly/2j94eGk.

As we mark today's 44th anniversary of the Roe v. Wade decision, the threats to women’s health are the most serious in a generation.  Improved access to contraception for American women has reduced the abortion rate to its lowest level ever. Yet President Donald Trump and Congressional Republicans want to make contraception harder to obtain, prevent women from making their own reproductive health care decisions, and even “punish” women who exercise their right to safe and legal abortion.  To stop this assault on reproductive freedom, women and men of all generations need to come together, make our voices heard, and hold President Trump and Republicans accountable for attacking our rights and our basic health care.

Yesterday, a top adviser to President Trump said The White House's false claims about inauguration crowd sizes were "alternative facts" — an artful word for propaganda. When our national security is at stake, Donald Trump's "alternative facts" could put American lives at risk.  The American people deserve an honest, accountable President, not one who peddles falsehoods and propaganda.

REMINDER: Join me for my next town hall meeting on Thursday, January 26 from 6:30 to 7:30 p.m. in the auditorium Neighborhood House at the Wellstone Center.  Just days after President Trump's inauguration and the historic Women's March, there is a lot to discuss. I hope to see you there and hear from you directly.

The Constitution’s Emoluments Clause is clear: No officer of the United States can earn money from foreign governments. Four days into his term, President Trump is already flouting this key part of the Constitution in an effort to profit from the Presidency.   I support this essential public interest lawsuit to enforce our Constitution and hold President Trump accountable to the American people.

President Donald Trump has nominated a cabinet of billionaires and individuals with serious conflicts of interests, like Scott Pruitt — the nominee to lead the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.   The American people, Democrats and Republicans, expect the President and his appointees to operate in an honest, accountable manner. To that end, I voted today FOR a new House Appropriations Committee rule that would have required all Trump administration officials who testify before our committee to certify that they are complying with their Office of Government Ethics ethics agreements.  I'm deeply disappointed that House Republicans blocked this common-sense proposal and turned back an opportunity to guarantee honest and accountable government.

I strongly oppose President Donald Trump's executive actions that move forward with the Dakota Access and Keystone XL pipelines despite environmental concerns presenting severe risks to clean water and the health of our planet.   I stand with sovereign tribes, including the Standing Rock Sioux, and local communities in support of their right to have input on projects that could have devastating impacts on their way of life. We must put people and our planet before corporate profits.

Without any proof at all, President Donald Trump is falsely claiming that millions of people voted illegally in the 2016 presidential election. All Americans should be deeply concerned about these blatant falsehoods coming from our Commander-in-Chief.  I agree with the Financial Times' Gideon Rachman, who writes:  “What we are witnessing is the destruction of credibility of the American government. This spectacle of obvious lies being peddled by the White House is a tragedy for US democracy. But the rest of the world — and, in particular, America’s allies — should also be very frightened. A Trump administration that is addicted to the ‘big lie’ has very dangerous implications for global security.”  You can read his full column here: http://on.ft.com/2knYxlB.

TOMORROW: Join me tomorrow night, Thursday, January 26, from 6:30 to 7:30 p.m. at Neighborhood House at the Wellstone Center for my next town hall meeting.   Just days after President Donald Trump's inauguration and historic turnout for the Women's March in Minnesota and across America, we have a lot to discuss.

Our broken campaign finance system allows billionaires and corporations to dump millions of dollars to advance their special interests. This flow of unregulated money weakens our democracy and hurts the American people.  I support accountable, honest government, which is why I am co-sponsoring the Democracy for All Amendment. This legislation would amend the United States Constitution to overturn Citizens United and once again give the American people the power to regulate campaign contributions from special interests.

I am working with my colleagues on the House Appropriations Committee urging House Speaker Paul Ryan to enforce federal ethics laws and ensure Trump appointees follow them.   I am particularly concerned about Scott Pruitt, a close ally of the fossil fuel industry and President Trump's nominee to be EPA Administrator. Mr. Pruitt is entangled in litigation against the EPA on the side of the oil and gas industry, presenting an unacceptable conflict of interest should he be confirmed to lead the EPA.  I strongly support an accountable, honest government for the American people. I will keep working to enforce our ethics laws and ensure President Trump and his appointees follow them.

TONIGHT: Join me at Neighborhood House at the Wellstone Center for a Fourth District town hall meeting.   Just days into President Donald Trump's administration and on the heels of a historic turnout for the Women's March in Minnesota and across America, I want to hear from you directly about your priorities and your concerns.

I met today with leaders from the Center for Victims of Torture to discuss our shared opposition to President Donald Trump's proposals to reintroduce the use of torture by the United States government.   I unequivocally reject the use of torture by our Armed Forces and intelligence agencies because it doesn’t work, it puts American service members and officials at risk, and it violates the core American value of human rights. If President Trump pushes to legalize torture as a weapon against prisoners, I will fight to stop him.
We're live at Neighborhood House at the Wellstone Center for my town hall meeting. Follow along here.

Thank you to another overflow crowd that filled Neighborhood House at the Wellstone Center tonight for my town hall meeting! I enjoyed talking to you about what we can do, together, to fight President Trump's dangerous agenda.  I look forward to continuing our conversation in the weeks and months ahead. Look out for details on more upcoming town halls soon!
Thank you, Minnesota Nurses Association, for stopping by my office today to discuss how the Affordable Care Act is working for people across our community and our country. We must protect our care!

President Donald Trump's executive order targeting refugees and Muslim immigrants is cruel, betrays our values as Americans, and does nothing to enhance national security.   Congressional Republicans must not silently support President Trump’s action out of political fear while thousands of fully-vetted refugees now fear for their lives. This is not a time for political cowardice, but for courage in the face of a policy that will needlessly destroy lives.   Republicans and Democrats must stand united as Americans and reject this extreme presidential action. Anything less is to be complicit in President Trump's cruel attack on immigrants and refugees.

It is outrageous that Stephen Bannon, an alt-right media figure who built his career catering to anti-Semites and white supremacists, is replacing the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the table advising President Donald Trump on pressing national security issues.  When it comes to national security, we need careful and informed decision making, not an alt-right and alternative facts approach that threatens the safety of Americans.

I extend my condolences to the families, loved ones, and friends of those killed in the hate crime attack on the Islamic Cultural Center of Quebec and offer my continued prayers for the recovery of all those hurt in this attack.  We must stand united with all of our diverse communities and speak out against bigotry, discrimination, and hatred.
"Republicans in Congress who remain quiet or tacitly supportive of the ban should recognize that history will remember them as cowards." — The New York Times Editorial Board.

I am co-sponsoring the Statue of Liberty Values Act, the SOLVE Act, to invalidate President Trump’s executive order banning refugees, discriminating against Muslim immigrants, and targeting Muslim Americans returning to the United States.  With House Democrats and Senate Democrats standing united in opposition to this order, Congressional Republicans must speak up and join us in supporting legislation to end this order. This is no time for political cowardice. Instead, Republican leaders in Minnesota and across the United States should show courage in the face of a policy that threatens to destroy lives.

I support the hundreds of State Department officials — many with decades of foreign policy experience — who have expressed grave concerns about President Donald Trump's executive order that bans refugees, discriminates against Muslim immigrants, and targets Muslim Americans returning to the United States.  Our diplomatic professionals are our eyes and ears around the world. It is their job to bring both the information that they have gathered and the concerns that they have to the President and his administration. It is deeply disturbing that White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer is bullying and intimidating State Department professionals for doing their jobs.

The architect of President Donald Trump's plans for the Environmental Protection Agency has revealed his deeply disturbing vision: crippling environmental protection by cutting the EPA's budget in half and laying off two-thirds of its workforce. These cuts are unacceptable and would put the health and safety of the American people at grave risk.  As the lead Democrat on the House Appropriations Subcommittee that funds the EPA, I will keep fighting to ensure that we uphold our national commitment to clean air, clean water, and the health of our planet.

I share your fear and outrage that Stephen Bannon, an "alt-right" media figure who built his career catering to anti-Semites and white supremacists, has been given a seat on the National Security Council.  When it comes to our national security, we need experts offering clear and informed advice, not an "alt-right" political hack spewing alternative facts.  I am co-sponsoring the Protect the National Security Council from Political Interference Act to ensure that Mr. Bannon is not able to impose his dangerous worldview and his scorched earth political approach on our country’s most sensitive national security decisions.

Thank you to leaders of Minnesota's Private Colleges for meeting with me today. I appreciated our conversation about how we can increase college access, especially by supporting the Pell Grant program.

After Republicans used outrageously partisan tactics to deny President Obama’s eminently qualified Supreme Court nominee a fair hearing, President Donald Trump has launched an all-out attack on our rights as Americans with his nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court.  Make no mistake: Judge Gorsuch is a radical choice for the Supreme Court. If confirmed, he will be a vote to end a woman’s right to choose, reverse progress on LGBT rights, and champion the interests of big business over working families. It is a deeply disturbing fact that Judge Gorsuch is the architect of the Hobby Lobby decision, which allowed employers to deny female employees access to contraception.  The Supreme Court is the final guardian of both our Constitution and our rights as Americans. With his far-right views, we cannot trust Judge Gorsuch to uphold either the Constitution or the freedoms we enjoy in the United States. The Senate must reject the Gorsuch nomination.

ICYMI: I'm co-sponsoring legislation to negate President Trump's appointment of alt-right propagandist Stephen Bannon to the National Security Council.  When it comes to our national security, we need experts offering clear and informed advice, not an "alt-right" political hack spewing alternative facts. We must stop Mr. Bannon from imposing his dangerous worldview and scorched-earth politics on our country’s most sensitive national security decisions.

It is shameful that thousands of veterans who helped clean up American nuclear test sites are being denied access to the health care.  To fix this blatant inequity, I have co-sponsored the bipartisan Mark Takai Atomic Veterans Healthcare Parity Act to ensure that these receive the healthcare and benefits that they earned in service to our country.

Regardless of her income or her insurance policy, each woman should be able to access comprehensive health care services that are right for her and her family. For years, the Hyde Amendment has limited that access, especially for low-income women and women of color.  I am co-sponsoring the EACH Woman Act, which would overturn the Hyde Amendment and help ensure that all women have access to comprehensive reproductive health care, including safe and legal abortion.

I was officially approved today to serve another term as Ranking Member of the Interior-Environment Appropriations Subcommittee, which funds the Department of the Interior, the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Endowment for the Arts and the Humanities, and many agencies important to Native Americans.  As the top Democrat on the Interior-Environment Subcommittee, I will stand up and fight against President Trump and Republicans’ plans to attack environmental protection, sell our public lands, and defund the arts and humanities.

Don't let House Republicans fool you: the only "plans" they have for the Affordable Care Act would hurt families in Minnesota and across the United States.  Just today, House Republican leaders debuted a proposal that would strip away many of the ACA's protections and let insurance companies once again discriminate against people with pre-existing conditions.  I will keep standing shoulder to shoulder with my Democratic colleagues to save the Affordable Care Act and protect our care.

I voted NO this afternoon on a Republican bill to weaken the background check system that helps prevent gun violence.  Under federal gun safety laws dating to 1968, people with very severe, long-term, mental disorders are not allowed to purchase firearms because of the danger they may pose to themselves and others. This Republican legislation, H.J. Res. 40, rescinds a very narrowly tailored rule that improves reporting of people with very severe, long-term, mental disorders to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System so that the law is enforced and potentially dangerous people cannot buy guns.  This Republican bill is just another part of President Trump and House Republicans’ gun lobby-backed agenda to weaken common sense gun violence prevention measures and make our families and communities less safe.

Khizr Khan came to national prominence when he spoke during the 2016 presidential campaign about then-candidate Donald Trump's proposals to discriminate against Muslims.  Mr. Khan and his wife, Ghazala, are the parents of U.S. Army Captain Humayun Khan, who was killed during the Iraq War and was posthumously awarded a Purple Heart and Bronze Star.  After Mr. and Mrs. Khan came forward, Mr. Trump repeatedly attacked them. The Khans responded with quiet dignity — and a fierce defense of our country's basic values.  I was honored to stand with Mr. Khan today for the introduction of the Freedom of Religion Act, which challenges President Trump's discriminatory executive order.  Thank you, Mr. and Mrs. Khan, for your perseverance and for your commitment to an America where people of all religions, or no religion at all, are respected, valued, and treated with dignity.

House Republicans are at it again: They just attacked workers' rights by voting to weaken enforcement of laws that require fair pay and safe workplaces.  I strongly oppose H.J. Res. 37, which blocks an Obama administration rule that cracked down on government contractors who have repeatedly endangered the safety of their employees or cheated their workers out of the pay they have earned.   To build an America where everyone has the opportunity to participate and succeed, we should be supporting working families, not making it easier for companies to abuse them.

St. Paul is the setting for a moving video by The New York Times about the impact of President Donald Trump's cruel refugee ban. Closing our doors to a refugee family fleeing Myanmar in search of a better life makes a mockery of our values.  It is time for Republicans to join Democrats and overturn President Trump's harmful policy.

Our democracy relies on the basic trust that our public servants tell the American people the truth. Unfortunately, many of the top advisors to President Donald Trump seem to have a reckless disregard for the truth.  Now that Counselor to the President Kellyanne Conway and other Trump advisors are in the White House, they must be held to a higher standard. It is past time for them to stop with the blatantly false statements and “alternative facts.”

Betsy DeVos, President-elect Donald Trump’s nominee for Secretary of Education, has a disturbing track record of attacking public education in America and funding an extremist agenda that weakens our public schools.  Ms. DeVos has no experience in public education other than partisan lobbying to slash funding for public schools, demonize public school teachers, and promote for-profit schooling beginning in kindergarten.  I am glad that our Senators, U.S. Senator Al Franken and Amy Klobuchar, are being our voice and opposing this deeply misguided nomination. I urge Republican Senators to join them and defeat DeVos.

As we mark Black History Month this February, it's a great time to learn more about the Penumbra Theatre Company in St. Paul.  Penumbra was founded in 1976 to "create a forum for African-American voices in the Twin Cities’ well-respected theater community." In the 40 years since, Penumbra has become a beloved community treasure and a venue for outstanding, culturally-relevant theater productions.  Learn more about Penumbra and check out their upcoming shows here → https://penumbratheatre.org/.

The Minnesota Department of Transportation is hard at work on the planned reconstruction of the St. Paul High Bridge, which will begin this fall.  To gather input on design plans, MnDOT is giving you an opportunity to make your voices heard at a public forum. The meeting will be held from 5 to 7 p.m. tomorrow at Bad Weather Brewing Company, located at 414 W. Seventh St. in St. Paul.

I was honored to speak to United South and Eastern Tribes, Inc. this morning about the progress we have made on Native American education and health care and how I am leading a bipartisan coalition in Congress to defend it.

Millions of American children rely on the Affordable Care Act to access the health care they need. I stood today with children and parents who are covered under the ACA, Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program — and are worried about what President Trump and House Republicans' ACA repeal proposal will mean for them.   For these families and for millions like them in Minnesota and across the United States, we must stand together and protect our care. As the legendary Marian Wright Edelman of the Children's Defense Fund said today: "We're not going back!"

President Donald Trump and Congressional Republicans' proposed repeal of the Affordable Care Act will risk health care coverage for nearly 300,000 Minnesotans enrolled in Medical Assistance and MinnesotaCare, according to a new issue brief from the Minnesota Department of Human Services.   For the sake of these 300,000 Minnesotans and their families, we must stand united and protect our care.

I voted NO tonight on Republican legislation, H.J. Res. 44, which makes it harder for the federal government to consider science, especially climate science, as it makes decisions about how to best manage our public lands.   This legislation is yet another example of how President Donald Trump and Congressional Republicans are working to remove science from policy making in order to tilt outcomes toward special interests like the oil and gas industry.

I led a group of Democrats and Republicans writing to President Donald Trump today urging him to exempt programs that serve Native Americans from his federal hiring freeze.  There is a chronic shortage of doctors, teachers, and law enforcement officers throughout Indian Country. Unless an exemption is made, this hiring freeze will exacerbate that problem, potentially putting lives at risk.  I will keep working on a bipartisan basis to uphold our trust and treaty obligations to American Indians and Alaska Natives.

Counselor to the President Kellyanne Conway today used her official role to promote President Donald Trump's daughter's line of clothing, shoes, jewelry, and fragrances. As a senior government official speaking on federal property, Ms. Conway's comments are almost certainly a violation of federal ethics rules.   Now that Ms. Conway and other aides to President Trump are in the White House, they must follow federal ethics standards and laws. When it comes to the Paris Agreement, "The entire world has signed on, save only Syria and Nicaragua. It appears that Donald Trump now means to expand that group of two to include the United States of America."  Every American who believes in science, environmental protection, and a sustainable future must stand up, speak out, and fight back against this dangerous White House. Together with the world community, responsible Americans must not allow President Trump to unilaterally threaten our planet.

I agree with Minnesota's business community: The Paris Agreement is "not only the right thing to do for people and the environment, it is also good business.”  If President Donald Trump withdraws from the Paris Agreement today, our families, our businesses, and our environment will all suffer. Together with the world community, responsible Americans must not allow President Trump to unilaterally threaten our planet.

In the words of Bloomberg Businessweek, "The potential consequences of Washington abandoning the climate pact would be grave not only for the planet but also for the U.S., its economic competitiveness, technological innovation, and leadership of the world in the 21st century."  Climate change is the greatest environmental threat facing our planet and the next generation of humanity. Instead of constructive leadership and action, President Trump and the Republican Congress are willing to renounce the Paris Agreement, make the United States an environmental rogue nation, and condemn the next generation to the hell of an overheated planet. That's just wrong.

The GOP needs to learn from Minnesota common sense and get on with the business of growing jobs, powering our planet, and fueling our economy with a clean energy future.

President Donald Trump should have listened to American military leaders: climate change is already contributing to a less stable world and multiplying our national security threats. Every American who believes in science, environmental protection, and a sustainable future must stand up, speak out, and fight back against this dangerous White House. Together with the world community, responsible Americans must not allow President Trump to unilaterally threaten our planet.

As our allies and partners vow to continue the fight against global warming, President Donald Trump has declared a unilateral surrender.   President Trump's decision today makes him a pariah in the international community and severely damages the United States’ credibility among our allies. The world community cannot trust President Trump and neither should the American people.

Leaving the Paris Agreement on climate change is a devastating mistake that will likely carry tragic consequences, but it is only one part of President Donald Trump’s disastrous polluters-first agenda – including his backwards budget. No matter what President Trump does, we cannot go backwards.
